thread.title: Accountants Confident in U.S. Economic Outlook

author: Ezequiel Minaya
title: Accountants Confident in U.S. Economic Outlook
text:
1 COMMENTS US President Donald Trump arrives to speak about tax cuts during an event with American workers in the Rose Garden of the White House in Washington, DC, April 12, 2018. Photo: saul loeb/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images 
The people who watch the books at U.S. companies grew more confident about the economy in early 2018 as Washington began to implement an overhaul of the tax code, according to a global survey of accountants.
The latest quarterly survey by the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants and the Institute of Management Accountants found that 38% of respondents in North America were “feeling more confident about the future,” up from 31% in the prior report. Roughly 26% of respondents in North America expressed more pessimism, flat compared with the previous three-month period.
The Global Economic Conditions Survey polled 1,418 accountants between Feb. 27 and March 15.
“The increase in confidence comes on the back of massive tax cuts which should help boost consumption, increase wage growth and lead to lower unemployment rates,” the report noted. Legislation completed in December lowered the corporate tax rate to 21% from 35%.
Globally, economic confidence is at its strongest since the inception of the survey in 2009. The uptick began in the middle of last year, said Narayanan Vaidyanathan, head of business insights for ACCA, in an interview with CFO Journal.
“I think it’s something very unusual,” he said. “Various bits of the world have been limping back [from the financial crisis] and it’s coming together in a robust way.”
Part of the reason, Mr. Vaidyanathan said, is the boost that has come from low interest rates at central banks seeking to foster economic growth..
According to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, which tracks 35 member countries from the Americas to Europe and Asia, the short-term outlook is for stable growth overall.
Simultaneous growth among countries the OECD tracks is rare. The OECD economies grew in concert for part of the last decade, in the late 1980s and for a few years before the 1973 oil crisis.
There are potential headwinds, however, Mr. Vaidyanathan added. In the U.S., doubts over the outlook for interest rates may shake confidence. Tension over trade between Washington and Beijing is also being closely watched, he said.
“We are in rather uncertainty time geopolitically in terms in relationships between various big powers around the world,” Mr. Vaidyanathan said.
